title: 1. Concept of Basic Electrical and Electronics Engineering

questions.questionText: Ohm’s law states the relation between:
questions.explanation: Ohm’s law states V = I × R, which relates voltage, current, and resistance.

questions.questionText: Unit of electric current is:
questions.explanation: The SI unit of current is Ampere (A), which is the flow of one Coulomb per second.

questions.questionText: Resistance is inversely proportional to:
questions.explanation: Resistance R = ρL/A, hence inversely proportional to the conductor’s cross-sectional area.

questions.questionText: 1 Volt is defined as:
questions.explanation: 1 Volt means 1 Joule of work done to move 1 Coulomb of charge.

questions.questionText: The SI unit of resistance is:
questions.explanation: The unit of resistance is Ohm (Ω), defined as 1 Volt per 1 Ampere.

questions.questionText: Current flowing in a conductor is directly proportional to:
questions.explanation: From Ohm’s law, I = V/R, so current increases with voltage for constant resistance.

questions.questionText: The reciprocal of resistance is called:
questions.explanation: Conductance (G) = 1/R, measured in Siemens (S).

questions.questionText: One ampere means flow of:
questions.explanation: 1 Ampere = 1 Coulomb of charge flowing per second.

questions.questionText: If current doubles in a resistor, the voltage will:
questions.explanation: Ohm’s law: V = IR, so if current doubles, voltage also doubles (for constant R).

questions.questionText: The resistance of a wire increases with:
questions.explanation: Resistance R = ρL/A increases directly with length.

questions.questionText: Copper is preferred as a conductor because:
questions.explanation: Copper has very low resistivity, making it an excellent conductor.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is an insulator?
questions.explanation: Glass does not allow current flow easily and acts as an insulator.

questions.questionText: Ohm’s law is valid for:
questions.explanation: Ohm’s law holds true for metallic conductors when temperature and other conditions are constant.

questions.questionText: The resistance of a conductor depends on:
questions.explanation: Resistance depends on length, area, resistivity, and temperature of the conductor.

questions.questionText: A material that allows electric current to flow easily is:
questions.explanation: Conductors like copper and aluminum allow current to pass easily due to free electrons.

questions.questionText: The unit of electrical power is:
questions.explanation: Power is the rate of doing electrical work, measured in Watts (W).

questions.questionText: Energy consumed by a device is given by:
questions.explanation: Electrical energy = Power × Time = P × t.

questions.questionText: A 100 W bulb consumes how much energy in 10 hours?
questions.explanation: Energy = 100 W × 10 h = 1000 Wh = 1 kWh, but wait carefully: 100 × 10 = 1000 Wh = 1 kWh → Correct answer is 1 kWh.

questions.questionText: 1 kWh = ? Joules
Electrical power formula is:
questions.explanation: Power can be expressed as P = VI, P = I²R, or P = V²/R.

questions.questionText: A 60 W bulb is operated for 2 hours. Energy consumed is:
questions.explanation: Energy = Power × Time = 60 W × 2 h = 120 Wh.

questions.questionText: Efficiency of a system is:
questions.explanation: Efficiency = (Useful output power / Input power) × 100%.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a unit of electrical energy?
questions.explanation: Energy is measured in Joules (J), while Watt is the unit of power.

questions.questionText: The electric bill is measured in:
questions.explanation: Electricity consumption is billed in kilowatt-hours (kWh).

questions.questionText: Maximum power transfer theorem states maximum power is delivered when:
questions.explanation: According to maximum power transfer theorem, maximum power is transferred when load resistance equals source resistance.

questions.questionText: In series connection, current through each resistor is:
questions.explanation: In a series circuit, the same current flows through all components.

questions.questionText: In parallel connection, voltage across each resistor is:
questions.explanation: In parallel, all resistors share the same voltage across them.

questions.questionText: Equivalent resistance of resistors in series is:
questions.explanation: For series connection, total resistance = R1 + R2 + … + Rn.

questions.questionText: Equivalent resistance of resistors in parallel is:
questions.explanation: For parallel: 1/Req = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + … + 1/Rn.

questions.questionText: In a series circuit, total voltage is:
questions.explanation: In series, voltages add up while current remains the same.

questions.questionText: In a parallel circuit, total current is:
questions.explanation: In parallel, the supply current splits into branches and adds up.

questions.questionText: Voltage divider rule is applicable in:
questions.explanation: The voltage divider rule applies only in series circuits.

questions.questionText: Current divider rule is applicable in:
questions.explanation: The current divider rule applies only in parallel circuits.

questions.questionText: If two equal resistors are connected in parallel, equivalent resistance is:
questions.explanation: Two equal resistors in parallel give Req = R/2.

questions.questionText: Three resistors of 2Ω, 3Ω, 6Ω connected in parallel. Equivalent resistance is:
Current in parallel resistors divides according to:
questions.explanation: Current splits inversely proportional to resistance values.

questions.questionText: Equivalent resistance is maximum when resistors are connected in:
questions.explanation: In series, resistances add up, giving maximum equivalent resistance.

questions.questionText: Equivalent resistance is minimum when resistors are connected in:
questions.explanation: In parallel, resistances reduce, making equivalent resistance minimum.

questions.questionText: Which of the following follows Ohm’s law?
questions.explanation: Ohm’s law applies to both series and parallel resistive circuits.

questions.questionText: In parallel circuit, the total resistance is always:
questions.explanation: Parallel combination always gives Req smaller than the smallest branch resistance.

questions.questionText: Star to delta transformation is used for:
questions.explanation: Star–delta transformation is mainly used to simplify complex resistor networks.

questions.questionText: In star connection, line current =:
questions.explanation: In star connection, line current is equal to phase current.

questions.questionText: In delta connection, line voltage =:
questions.explanation: In delta, line voltage is equal to phase voltage.

questions.questionText: The star-delta transformation relates:
options: Three resistors in star ↔ three in delta
questions.explanation: It is a method to convert a three-resistor star to equivalent three-resistor delta and vice versa.

questions.questionText: Star to delta conversion formula involves:
questions.explanation: The formulas use both product of opposite arms and sum of resistances, so ‘All’ is correct.

questions.questionText: Delta to star conversion is useful in:
questions.explanation: Delta–star conversion is used for simplifying complex circuits.

questions.questionText: In balanced 3-phase star connection, phase angle difference between lines is:
questions.explanation: The three-phase system has 120° phase difference between lines.

questions.questionText: In delta connection, each phase winding is connected:
options: End to end in closed loop
questions.explanation: In delta, windings are connected end-to-end forming a closed loop.

questions.questionText: Which gives higher line current for same load?
questions.explanation: Delta connection gives higher line current compared to star for same load.

questions.questionText: Star connection requires:
questions.explanation: Star has lower phase voltage, hence requires less insulation.

questions.questionText: Delta connection requires:
questions.explanation: Delta has phase voltage equal to line voltage, requiring more insulation.

questions.questionText: Neutral wire is possible in:
questions.explanation: Neutral wire can be taken from the common star point.

questions.questionText: A star-delta starter is used in:
questions.explanation: Star–delta starter is commonly used to start induction motors.

questions.questionText: In star-delta starter, voltage across motor during starting is reduced to:
questions.explanation: In star starting, each winding gets V/√3, reducing starting voltage.

questions.questionText: The purpose of delta to star conversion is:
questions.explanation: Delta–star conversion simplifies the circuit for easier analysis.

questions.questionText: Kirchhoff’s current law (KCL) is based on:
questions.explanation: KCL is based on conservation of charge — total charge entering a node equals total leaving.

questions.questionText: KCL states:
options: Sum of currents at a node is zero
Sum of voltages around loop is zero
questions.explanation: KCL: algebraic sum of currents at a node is zero (incoming = outgoing).

questions.questionText: Kirchhoff’s voltage law (KVL) is based on:
questions.explanation: KVL is based on conservation of energy — energy gained equals energy lost in a closed loop.

questions.questionText: KVL states:
options: Sum of voltages around closed loop = 0
Voltage is constant in parallel circuit
questions.explanation: KVL: algebraic sum of all voltages in a closed loop is zero.

questions.questionText: KCL applies to:
questions.explanation: KCL applies at junctions where currents meet.

questions.questionText: KVL applies to:
questions.explanation: KVL applies around closed loops of a circuit.

questions.questionText: In KCL, currents entering node are taken as:
questions.explanation: By convention, entering currents are positive, leaving are negative.

questions.questionText: In KVL, voltages drop and rise are taken with:
questions.explanation: Voltage rise and drop must be considered with opposite signs for correct summation.

questions.questionText: KCL is true for:
questions.explanation: KCL is valid for both AC and DC circuits.

questions.questionText: KVL is true for:
questions.explanation: KVL is also valid for both AC and DC circuits.

questions.questionText: Which theorem is derived from KVL and KCL?
questions.explanation: All these theorems use KVL and KCL in their derivations.

questions.questionText: Kirchhoff’s laws fail in circuits with:
questions.explanation: In circuits with strong magnetic coupling or varying fields, Kirchhoff’s laws may not hold.

questions.questionText: KCL can also be called:
questions.explanation: KCL is often called the junction rule since it applies at nodes.

questions.questionText: KVL can also be called:
questions.explanation: KVL is also known as the loop rule since it applies to closed loops.

questions.questionText: Applying KCL at a node with 3A entering and 2A leaving, the remaining current is:
questions.explanation: By KCL, if 3 A enters and 2 A leaves, 1 A must leave to balance currents.

questions.questionText: An open circuit means:
questions.explanation: In an open circuit, resistance is infinite and no current flows.

questions.questionText: A short circuit means:
questions.explanation: In a short circuit, resistance is zero and current is very high.

questions.questionText: A series circuit has:
questions.explanation: In series, the same current flows through all components.

questions.questionText: A parallel circuit has:
questions.explanation: In parallel, the voltage across all branches is the same.

questions.questionText: Which circuit is safer in household wiring?
questions.explanation: Household wiring uses parallel circuits so each appliance gets full voltage.

questions.questionText: A closed circuit means:
questions.explanation: A closed circuit provides a complete path for current to flow.

questions.questionText: Which type of circuit is used in Christmas lights where one bulb failure breaks the circuit?
questions.explanation: Old-style Christmas lights used series circuits, so one bulb failure broke the entire chain.

questions.questionText: Which type of circuit continues working if one branch fails?
questions.explanation: In a parallel circuit, other branches continue working even if one fails.

questions.questionText: In an open switch, the circuit is:
questions.explanation: An open switch breaks the path, making the circuit open.

questions.questionText: In a closed switch, the circuit is:
questions.explanation: A closed switch completes the circuit, allowing current to flow.

questions.questionText: If a wire accidentally touches both terminals of a battery, it causes:
questions.explanation: Direct contact of battery terminals creates a short circuit.

questions.questionText: A fuse is used to protect against:
questions.explanation: Fuse protects circuits from excessive current caused by short circuits.

questions.questionText: Equivalent resistance of a short circuit is:
questions.explanation: A short circuit has zero resistance.

questions.questionText: Equivalent resistance of an open circuit is:
questions.explanation: An open circuit has infinite resistance.

questions.questionText: Which is more commonly used in electrical distribution?
questions.explanation: Parallel circuits are used in distribution for uniform voltage.

questions.questionText: In a parallel circuit, if one bulb fuses:
questions.explanation: In parallel, other bulbs glow as each branch is independent.

questions.questionText: Which circuit uses less wire?
questions.explanation: Series circuits use less wire compared to parallel circuits.

questions.questionText: Which circuit is more reliable?
questions.explanation: Parallel circuits are more reliable since each branch works independently.

questions.questionText: A flashlight usually uses:
questions.explanation: Flashlights generally connect batteries in series to increase voltage.

questions.questionText: Car headlights are usually connected in:
questions.explanation: Car headlights are connected in parallel, so if one fails the other still works.

questions.questionText: Which circuit is used in power transmission lines?
questions.explanation: Parallel distribution ensures constant voltage supply to consumers.

questions.questionText: Series circuits are rarely used in homes because:
options: If one device fails, all stop
questions.explanation: In series, failure of one device stops current for all others.

questions.questionText: When two switches are connected in series, the circuit works like:
questions.explanation: Both switches must be ON in series → behaves like AND gate.

questions.questionText: When two switches are connected in parallel, the circuit works like:
questions.explanation: Either switch ON allows current → behaves like OR gate.

questions.questionText: Street lights controlled by one switch are connected in:
questions.explanation: Street lights are connected in parallel for equal brightness.

questions.questionText: The total current in a parallel circuit is:
questions.explanation: In parallel, total current = sum of individual branch currents.

questions.questionText: Total voltage in a series circuit is:
questions.explanation: In series, total voltage is the sum of voltages across each component.

questions.questionText: Which law is used to calculate currents in complex circuits?
questions.explanation: Kirchhoff’s laws are used for solving complex circuits.

questions.questionText: Household distribution board connects loads in:
questions.explanation: Loads are connected in parallel so each receives full voltage.

questions.questionText: Series-parallel combination circuits are:
questions.explanation: Most real circuits are series-parallel combinations.

questions.questionText: Superposition theorem is applicable only to:
questions.explanation: Superposition theorem applies only to linear circuits.

questions.questionText: Superposition theorem is based on the principle of:
questions.explanation: Superposition is valid due to linearity of the circuit.

questions.questionText: Superposition theorem cannot be applied to:
questions.explanation: It cannot directly calculate power since power depends on square of current or voltage.

options: Voltage source in parallel with resistance
Voltage source in series with resistance
Current source in parallel with resistance

options: Open-circuiting voltage sources, shorting current sources
Short-circuiting voltage sources, opening current sources

options: Voltage source in series with resistance
Current source in parallel with resistance
Voltage source in parallel with resistance
Current source in series with resistance

questions.questionText: Thevenin’s theorem simplifies:
options: Complex network to single voltage source

questions.questionText: Norton’s current is equal to:
questions.explanation: Norton current is the short-circuit current across terminals.

questions.questionText: Reciprocity theorem is valid for:
questions.explanation: Reciprocity applies only to linear bilateral networks.

questions.questionText: Superposition theorem is not applicable when:
questions.explanation: Presence of nonlinear elements invalidates superposition.

questions.questionText: In Thevenin’s theorem, Thevenin resistance is measured at:

questions.questionText: Thevenin’s equivalent can be used to analyze:

questions.questionText: Maximum power transfer efficiency at best is:

questions.questionText: Superposition principle is applied for:
questions.explanation: Superposition applies to linear equations.

questions.questionText: In AC circuit, Thevenin impedance is:

questions.explanation: Dependent sources are left as they are; they are not turned off.

questions.questionText: Which theorem is best for analyzing circuits with varying loads?
questions.explanation: Thevenin theorem is best for analyzing circuits with varying loads.

questions.questionText: Thevenin’s theorem was given by:
questions.explanation: Thevenin theorem is named after H. Thevenin.

questions.questionText: Norton’s theorem replaces a voltage source with:
questions.explanation: Norton converts voltage source to current source.

questions.questionText: Superposition theorem is not suitable for:

questions.questionText: Lagging power factor occurs in:

questions.questionText: Tropospheric ducting typically occurs at?
questions.explanation: Ducting occurs in VHF and UHF ranges when refractive index gradients trap waves in the troposphere.

questions.questionText: In plane earth propagation, path loss increases due to?
questions.explanation: Plane earth model considers direct and reflected rays; interference between them causes additional path loss.

questions.questionText: At frequencies above 30 MHz, the dominant mode of propagation is?
questions.explanation: Space wave propagation dominates above 30 MHz (VHF, UHF, microwave).

questions.questionText: The ionospheric F2 layer is most useful for communication because?
options: It has the highest electron density
It is unaffected by solar activity
questions.explanation: The F2 layer has the highest electron density, supporting long-distance HF communication.

questions.questionText: Free space path loss (FSPL) in dB is given by?
questions.explanation: FSPL (dB) = 20 log(d) + 20 log(f) + 32.44, with d in km and f in MHz.

questions.questionText: The skip distance in ionospheric propagation is defined as?
options: Shortest distance between transmitter and receiver for sky wave
Longest ground distance covered by ground wave
questions.explanation: Skip distance is the shortest distance between Tx and Rx via sky wave, below which no signal is received.

questions.questionText: The maximum range of ground wave propagation increases with?
options: Lower frequency and higher ground conductivity
questions.explanation: Ground waves travel farther at lower frequencies and over highly conductive surfaces like sea water.

questions.questionText: Which wave is most affected by the curvature of the Earth?
questions.explanation: Ground wave propagation closely follows Earth’s curvature and is affected by its conductivity and terrain.

questions.questionText: The reflection coefficient of ionospheric layers is close to?
questions.explanation: Ionospheric reflection is partial, so the reflection coefficient is between 0 and 1.

questions.questionText: Fading in HF communication is mainly due to?
options: Multiple propagation paths in the ionosphere
questions.explanation: Fading occurs when signals arrive with phase differences due to multipath ionospheric propagation.

questions.questionText: Tropospheric scatter communication is generally used for ranges up to?
questions.explanation: Tropospheric scatter can support communication links up to 2000 km using high power and sensitive receivers.

questions.questionText: The virtual height of an ionospheric layer is?
options: Apparent reflection height determined by measurement
questions.explanation: Virtual height is the apparent reflection height of ionospheric waves as determined from echo measurements.

questions.questionText: Atmospheric absorption of radio waves increases with?
questions.explanation: Higher frequencies (especially above 10 GHz) suffer higher atmospheric absorption due to oxygen and water vapor.

questions.questionText: The D-layer of the ionosphere primarily causes?
questions.explanation: The D-layer causes strong absorption of LF/MF signals during daytime, reducing ground wave effectiveness.

questions.questionText: At oblique incidence, the effective ionospheric path length compared to vertical incidence is?
questions.explanation: At oblique incidence, the path length is longer, leading to MUF > fc.

questions.questionText: The Brewster angle effect in radio wave propagation occurs when?
options: Reflection coefficient for parallel polarization becomes zero
Attenuation in the ionosphere is minimum
questions.explanation: At the Brewster angle, reflection coefficient for parallel polarization becomes zero, minimizing reflection loss.

questions.questionText: The relationship between virtual height (h’) and true height (h) of the ionospheric layer depends on?

questions.explanation: Virtual height exceeds true height due to reduced group velocity caused by electron density variation.

questions.questionText: Tropospheric ducting occurs when the refractivity gradient is less than?
questions.explanation: Ducting happens when refractivity gradient < -157 N-units/km, trapping waves close to Earth’s surface.

questions.questionText: The maximum range of sky-wave communication is limited by?
questions.explanation: The maximum range depends on skip distance, ionospheric layer height, and Earth’s curvature.

questions.questionText: Ionospheric storms affect HF communication primarily by?

questions.questionText: The phase velocity in an ionized medium can exceed c because?

questions.questionText: In multipath propagation, selective fading occurs because?
questions.explanation: Selective fading happens when multipath causes different frequency components of the signal to interfere destructively.

questions.questionText: The lowest usable frequency (LUF) for ionospheric communication is determined by?
questions.explanation: LUF is the lowest frequency that can propagate without excessive absorption in the ionosphere, especially the D-layer.

questions.questionText: The Fresnel zone concept is important in propagation because?
options: It defines regions of constructive/destructive interference
It only applies to ionospheric paths
questions.explanation: Fresnel zones define regions around the line of sight where reflections cause constructive or destructive interference.

questions.questionText: In satellite communication, rain fade is most severe in which frequency band?
questions.explanation: Rain attenuation is severe in Ku (12–18 GHz) and Ka (26–40 GHz) bands due to strong absorption/scattering by water droplets.

questions.questionText: The primary function of a transmitter is?

questions.questionText: Modulation is done to?

questions.explanation: Modulation shifts the baseband signal to higher frequency for transmission.

questions.questionText: In digital communication, information is represented by?
questions.explanation: Digital signals use discrete symbols or bits.

questions.questionText: Signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) measures?

questions.explanation: SNR = signal power / noise power.

questions.questionText: Baseband signal refers to?
questions.explanation: Baseband is the signal before modulation.

questions.questionText: In analog communication, AM stands for?
questions.explanation: AM varies the amplitude of the carrier proportional to the message.

questions.questionText: In analog communication, FM stands for?
questions.explanation: FM varies the frequency of the carrier according to the message.

questions.questionText: Noise is generally?
questions.explanation: Noise has random amplitude and phase variations.

questions.questionText: Bandwidth of a communication channel refers to?

questions.explanation: Channel bandwidth determines the range of frequencies it can transmit.

questions.questionText: In digital communication, bit is?

questions.questionText: Multiplexing is used to?

questions.explanation: Multiplexing allows efficient channel utilization.

questions.questionText: Demodulation is?

questions.explanation: Demodulation extracts information from the carrier.

questions.questionText: Amplitude of noise is usually?

questions.questionText: Channel in communication system refers to?
questions.explanation: Channel may be wired, wireless, or optical medium.

questions.questionText: A modulator is part of?
questions.explanation: Modulator prepares the signal for transmission.

questions.questionText: Digital signal has?
questions.explanation: Digital signals use discrete values (bits).

questions.questionText: In analog communication, SNR at the receiver can be improved by?
questions.explanation: Higher power and narrower bandwidth reduce noise relative to signal.

questions.questionText: Thermal noise power is proportional to?
questions.explanation: Thermal noise P = kTB, depends on temperature and bandwidth.

questions.questionText: Shot noise occurs due to?
questions.explanation: Shot noise is caused by random arrival of electrons or photons.

questions.questionText: Signal power in digital system is usually measured in?
questions.explanation: Signal power is expressed in watts or decibels relative to 1 mW.

questions.questionText: In AM, noise primarily affects?
questions.explanation: AM signals are sensitive to amplitude noise.

questions.questionText: In FM, noise effect is reduced by?
questions.explanation: FM noise immunity improves with larger frequency deviation.

questions.questionText: Shannon’s channel capacity depends on?
questions.explanation: C = B log2(1 + SNR).

questions.questionText: Multiplexing types include?
questions.explanation: TDM and FDM allow multiple signals over same channel.

questions.questionText: Baseband transmission uses?

questions.questionText: Bandpass transmission uses?

questions.explanation: Bandpass allows RF signals to propagate over channel.

questions.questionText: Pulse code modulation (PCM) is a type of?

questions.questionText: Quantization noise occurs in?
questions.explanation: Finite levels in digital sampling introduce quantization error.

questions.questionText: In a receiver, preamplifier improves?

questions.questionText: Thermal noise voltage across resistor R is proportional to?

questions.questionText: Digital communication advantages over analog include?

questions.explanation: Digital signals can be regenerated, reducing noise effects.

questions.questionText: In FM, pre-emphasis is used to?
questions.explanation: Pre-emphasis boosts high-frequency components to combat noise.

questions.questionText: De-emphasis in FM receiver is used to?
questions.explanation: De-emphasis restores signal after pre-emphasis.

questions.questionText: Nyquist rate defines?
options: Minimum sampling rate to avoid aliasing
questions.explanation: Sampling frequency ≥ 2 × highest signal frequency.

questions.questionText: Aliasing occurs when?
options: Sampling rate is below Nyquist rate
questions.explanation: Insufficient sampling causes overlapping frequency spectra.

questions.questionText: SNR improvement can be achieved by?
questions.explanation: Filters remove out-of-band noise, amplifiers boost signal.

questions.questionText: Matched filter in receiver maximizes?
questions.explanation: Matched filter optimally detects known signal in noise.

questions.questionText: Thermal noise power in a 1 kHz bandwidth at 300 K is approximately?
questions.explanation: P = k T B.

questions.explanation: Amplitude Shift Keying is amplitude sensitive.

questions.questionText: In FSK, noise affects?
questions.explanation: Frequency shift signals are sensitive to frequency-related noise.

questions.questionText: Digital communication allows error detection using?
questions.explanation: Redundant bits help detect transmission errors.

questions.questionText: PCM quantization level increase reduces?
questions.explanation: More levels mean smaller step size and less error.

questions.questionText: Delta modulation reduces?
questions.explanation: DM encodes differences, requiring fewer bits.

questions.questionText: In communication, fidelity refers to?
questions.explanation: High fidelity means output closely matches input.

questions.questionText: Digital signals are less affected by?
questions.explanation: Digital regeneration removes amplitude noise effectively.

questions.questionText: SNR improvement using spread spectrum is due to?
questions.explanation: Spreading reduces noise power density at receiver.

questions.questionText: In digital system, jitter refers to?
questions.explanation: Jitter causes bit errors in timing-sensitive systems.

questions.questionText: Eye diagram in digital communication is used to?

questions.explanation: Eye diagram shows intersymbol interference and noise effects.

questions.questionText: Shannon-Hartley theorem defines?
options: Channel capacity in presence of noise
questions.explanation: C = B log2(1 + SNR).

questions.questionText: In FM, threshold effect occurs when?
options: SNR falls below a critical level
questions.explanation: Below threshold, noise rises sharply in demodulated signal.

questions.questionText: Digital modulation schemes include?
questions.explanation: ASK, FSK, PSK encode information digitally.

questions.questionText: In digital system, intersymbol interference is caused by?
questions.explanation: ISI occurs when adjacent pulses overlap due to filtering or multipath.
